III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
The facility is located in a residential neighborhood in Westland, MI. The facility is a
two story, colonial style house, with four bedrooms and three bathrooms.
The exterior of the home is vinyl siding and brick. The home is less than 10 years old
and appears to be in excellent condition. The house is connected to city water and
sewer. Garbage collection is also through the city and is picked up on a weekly
basis. An Environmental Health inspection was completed on 11/26/13 and the
facility was given an A rating. A fire safety inspection was completed on 12/03/13
and the facility was given an A rating.
The first floor has a large living room, dining room, kitchen, bathroom, and family
room. All appliances in the kitchen appear to be clean and in working order. The
furniture, walls and floors appear to be clean and in good repair.
Medication for residents is located in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. Within the
cabinet, there are individual containers for each resident in order to keep medication
organized and separated.
The second floor has four bedrooms, two bathrooms, and storage closets for
bedding and towels. There are five available beds, all with clean linens. When
standing at the top of the stairs on the second floor bedrooms A & B are to the left
and bedrooms C & D are to the right. Bedrooms A, B and C have one full size bed
each. Bedroom D is the largest room and has two full size beds. The agency plans
to have four long term placements and utilize the fifth bed for a short term or respite
placement.
2

The basement level is locked and will not be used, except when access is needed to
service the furnace or hot water heater. A laundry room is located on the first floor
and has a working washer and dryer.
The facility has a fenced back yard with ample space for outdoor activities.
Schools in the area are less than five miles from the facility and provide bus
transportation.
The facility does not have a behavior management room.
B. Program Description
Genesis House is a five bed therapeutic residential facility for children, ages10-
17, with autism. The program plans to accept private placements and DHS
placements once they obtain a contract with DHS. The program description
states staffing will be a 3:1 ratio. However, the director reported that staffing will
likely be 2:1. When there are four residents, two staff will be on duty. However, if
a fifth resident came in as short term/respite placement, the ratio would be 3:1 for
that time.
After an intake assessment is complete and residents are accepted into the
program, a treatment plan will be developed which will include: self-care,
communication, motor skills, social skills, cognitive skills, daily living, and family
recreation. The program focuses on “normalizing life patters and each individual
achieving his/her maximum potential”. The goal of Genesis House is to provide
services to the child and their family, which will improve the youth’s daily living
skills and increase the parent’s knowledge base on raising a child with autism.
Through this, children and families will be empowered to have a more effective
relationship when the child returns to the family home.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
There were no rule violations found. During the licensing process, the facility was
given technical assistance in the following areas:
Rule 109 Program Statement- The agency was advised to document how they
plan to make the program statement available to parents and DHS. On 11/1/13,
Ms. Wood reported that the Program Statement has been added to the
admission/intake packet, to ensure that all parents/guardians and DHS receive
the statement at placement.
Rule 113 Employee Records- The agency was advised to add a CPS clearance
and verification of education to their new hire process. In addition, the agency
plans to utilize a Workforce Background Check. However they were advised that
3

they need to have a CPS check and ICHAT in the personnel file as well. On
11/1/13, Ms. Wood acknowledged this requirement and reported that it would be
added to the new hire checklist.
Rule 141 Initial Documentation- the agency’s “pre-admission form” and “child
information record” documented parts of rule 141, but not all of the required
information. The agency has revised the forms to comply with this rule.
Rule 167 Reporting Hospitalization or Death of a Resident- The agency was
advised to notify their licensing consultant of incidents regarding residents. In
addition, they were informed of DHS policy regarding injury, illness, or missing
child notification and the timeframes required.
The facility was provided consultation in the following areas:
PA 116- The agency was advised to document staff “hire date” and “start date”
separately. This recommendation was made after observing the agency’s
practice of documenting the “hire date” as when the offer for employment was
made, then completing clearances. The recommendation was made to show a
“start date” in order to show that clearances were completed prior to contact with
residents.
Additionally, several proposed agency forms were AFC documents. The agency
was advised to seek CWL forms from DHS or BCAL as they would better capture
the required information. The forms to be replaced were the “Resident Care
Agreement”, “Assessment Plan for Residents”, “Resident Funds Record”, and
“Health Appraisal”. On 11/1/13 Ms. Woods reported that all AFC forms were
replaced with CWL forms.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
The recommendation is to issue an original provisional license.
